CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 15, 1955, pg. 3, reads: "'Migrating Birds' - This is the title of the oil painting by Norman Lewis of New York, which is currently hanging in world-famous Pittsburgh International Exhibition of Contemporary Painting at Carnegie Institute in Oakland. The exhibition opens Thursday, Oct. 13. Although this newspaper, reproduction does not do justice to this work of art, you should attend the exhibit and view it, hanging on the wall of the stairway as you head towards the galleries.  The exhibition number is 174.  It is one of the most sensitive paintings you'll ever see, and the longer you look at it the more you see and understand.  The painting depicts migrating herons.  Mrs. James Diskin of the Fine Arts staff of Carnegie Institute views the painting. - Harris Photo."Related article published December 17, 1955, pg. 7, reads: "Popular Painting Prize - Painter Norman Lewis' entry in the 1955 Pittsburgh Carnegie International Art Exhibit, entitled 'Migrating Birds,' won this year's popular prize of $200 by vote of persons attending the exhibit, it was announced by Gordon Bailey Washburn, director of Fine Arts of Carnegie Institute, here Wednesday.  Lewis' works have been exhibited in Europe as well as the United States.  The painting has been purchased by as Pittsburgh collector."
TitMainTitle: Mrs. James Diskin standing next to Norman Lewis painting "Migrating Birds," at 1955 Carnegie International exhibition, Carnegie Museum of Art
